data.text: @SueRichart Right. Well, my mom, I think, was OK (but I never asked her how she was treated). But as black women, fibroids are common and a lot of times, when you do get to see the doctor, your symptoms aren't taken seriously.
@sunoppositemoon It's sad. The first thing I think is does your situation allow you to go to the doctor regularly? What a stupid country we live in.

I think it's only this year where I've had doctors kinda be dicks to me. And I'm not seeing them anymore. Oh, and there was another primary care physician earlier who was being like an android about my adult acne. Ugh. But usually, I feel heard, but I think this is rare.

But I don't know her medical journey with fibroids, if people pooh-poohed her complaints or took her seriously from jump. She was a nurse and is good at advocating for herself, but I don't know what she endured.

Before that, one day I remember we came home from church and she got up from the driver's seat--and there was blood. I don't know how big her fibroids were. She was done having kids. So I'm personally aware. And I'm close to her age of when she had that going on.
